> Members of the list have rightly been sceptical of my =
find as it is almost
> unheard of in the West, if I had not seen it myself =
I would not have
> believed it either. I have seen many swords with Muromac=
hi/Momoyama style
> koshirae over the years, but 99.9% have been 19th c. sw=
ords in retro style.
>
> Two exceptions come to mind: Victor Harris and I c=
atalogued the blades in
> the Museum of Japanese Sword Fittings in Tokyo fo=
r Christie's in '05. In
> that collection was a Momoyama tachi koshirae tha=
t was later sold in NY,
> the
> other was an itomaki tachi made for an Iked=
a Daimyo in Christie's London.
> Victor has seen this nagamaki and agrees t=
hat it is 16th c.
>
> I think this weapon is the first of a number of ident=
ical contract pieces
> for an armoury, as it is numbered '1' as are one sep=
pa, the fuchi and the
> tsuka in ink under the fuchi, it is utilitarian, wi=
th thin yamagane mounts
> and low quality lacquer, the nakago-ana are not w=
ell made. The long ububa
> can be accounted for by its lack of use, it may =
have been polished only
> once
> or twice then stored for a very long time,=
 this would account for its
> fairly
> good condition apart from the leathe=
r tsuka binding shrinking and being
> attacked by insects.
>
> It may look =
like a sword but it has the thick saya of a polearm, no
> kurikata
> and th=
e tsuka is 21.5" long.
>
> As I stated in my earlier post it weighs around =
6lbs, this is not something
>
> one would want as a personal weapon, it is =
too heavy and awkward to carry
> and I think would only be useful in battle=
.
>
